props.synopsis: Places and their names can hold different meanings for different people, but what happens when those in a community are uncomfortable with a historical figure or the association a place is named after?

title.children: Hundreds of places in Australia contain this 'racist slur' that experts want changed

image.altText: Four-year-old Chloe Valentine, who died in January 2012.

props.synopsis: Prominent child protection advocate Belinda Valentine has urged the South Australian government to rethink proposed law reforms, saying it's a "missed opportunity" to prevent further tragedies.

title.children: Child protection advocate urges SA government to rethink law reform

image.altText: An aerial shot of pine forestry plantations.

props.synopsis: A plan to build more than 100 wind turbines in pine plantations close to a unique wetland in south-west Victoria is out for public comment.

title.children: $1.2b wind farm plan for plantations near Ramsar-listed wetland

image.altText: person hauls a car along an iced road in the snow

props.synopsis: Adelaide's Aaron Crook is the sole Australian among 11 global competitors who will race each other 620 kilometres in temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius across the Arctic Circle.

title.children: Athlete ready to risk Arctic frostbite in 'hardest, most epic' race yet

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas wearing a navy suit sitting in an office.

props.synopsis: South Australia's politicians are heading back to parliament today for the first sitting week of 2025. Here are some of the key issues they will face this year.

title.children: The big political challenges confronting SA's major parties in 2025

image.altText: A man with a blonde beard wearing a blue stripy polo shirt and a baseball cap

props.synopsis: A defence lawyer has told a court that the evidence of a key witness in a criminal neglect trial against father Ashley McGregor was "simply unbelievable".

title.children: Key witness in criminal neglect trial against SA father 'simply unbelievable', court hears

image.altText: Aerial photo of end of island with aqua ocean rocky edge

props.synopsis: South Australia's fourth-largest island is set to become an ark for mammal species recovery, funded by $4.8 million from governments including ridding the island of rats, mice, and cats.

title.children: $4.8 million pledged to return island to the wild to save threatened species

image.altText: Kristen De Gilio leans her head into the head of her father John Kennedy

props.synopsis: John Kennedy suffered a sudden cardiac arrest at his Mount Barker home in April 2020. An inquest has heard his wife was told an ambulance was on its way when it had not yet been dispatched.

title.children: Inquest hears father would be alive if ambulance arrived sooner

image.altText: An aerial photo of a large estate on large well-kept lawns, overlooking a marina with docked boats on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: Several towns across South Australia will be part of a trial run by the state's electricity distributor to install batteries that it hopes will improve the grid's reliability, increase renewable energy use, and increase the speed at which electric vehicles can be charged.

title.children: Community battery trial a 'win-win-win' for small towns on end of powerline

image.altText: aerial shot of Adelaide's water desalination plant

props.synopsis: South Australia's reservoirs are back to the low levels of the Millennium Drought era. But most of us aren't facing water restrictions this time around, largely because the state has something it didn't have back then – a desalination plant.

title.children: Without its desalination plant, SA would probably have water restrictions again

image.altText: Smoke haze

props.synopsis: Temperatures have climbed above 40C in parts of SA, with health authorities confirming several people went to hospital over the weekend with "heat-related illness".

title.children: Weather bureau warns of 'significant' tree branch risk amid SA heat

image.altText: Three abalone shells sitting on a hessian sack.

props.synopsis: Divers off the coast of Port MacDonnell made a grim discovery last February, finding a disease that has sent shockwaves through the abalone industry.

title.children: SA's abalone industry on high alert as 'devastating' disease spreads

image.altText: A young man stands under words saying "Punter's Politics".

props.synopsis: A former high school teacher's satirical assault on Australian politics and its taxation failures hits home runs with everyday Australians and he has the federal election in his sights.

title.children: Punter's Politics uses satire to re-engage 'ripped off' Australians

image.altText: A politician in a suit with a white shirt walking into a building.

props.synopsis: When South Australian Liberal MP Tim Whetstone faced a challenge to his candidacy, the decision came down to just a few politically engaged party members in his electorate.

title.children: Dwindling membership leaves candidates' fate in hands of engaged few

image.altText: A collapsed wind turbine

props.synopsis: Authorities are working to investigate the collapse of a wind turbine at the Berrybank Wind Farm, west of Geelong.

title.children: Wind turbine collapse in Victoria's west prompts calls for safety audit

image.altText: A man and woman in a carriage, dressed in formal wear, pulled by a black horse team

props.synopsis: World champion carriage driver Boyd Exell returns home to Australia this year to help students learn the ropes of a sport with royal roots.

title.children: A carriage-driving master brings his skills back home

image.altText: view of a woman from behind opening curtains to morning sun

props.synopsis: A new peer-reviewed study of nearly 50,000 participants finds that people generally wake up feeling their happiest, and are in their worst frame of mind around midnight.

title.children: Morning people are generally happier, study finds

image.altText: Someone is holding up an Australian passport in the foreground. The background, which is out of focus, is a lemon tree.

props.synopsis: Passport photos aren't typically creative or flattering. But at one time, they were artistic and had elaborate backdrops.

title.children: The evolution of passports around the globe

image.altText: A fire-damaged building

props.synopsis: A popular Tasmanian vet clinic on Hobart's eastern shore, which treats 100 animals a day, has been left reeling after a fire in the roof just a year since it completed a $4 million upgrade.

title.children: 'Going to be difficult': Services to be impacted after fire at major Hobart vet clinic

image.altText: A person looks down at the screen of a laptop

props.synopsis: There's a growing push in Australia's medical circles to do away with antiquated fax machines amid concerns the country's medical referral and documentation system is outdated.

title.children: Calls to 'axe the fax'. Why do medical specialists still use fax machines?

image.altText: mastercard

props.synopsis: Physical credit cards, numberless or not, will soon become redundant, as biometric payment options become more popular.

title.children: Mastercard is scrapping credit card numbers by 2030 as cards become obsolete

image.altText: Car driving through flood waters

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) is warning more than 200 millimetres could still fall on Townsville, Ingham and surrounds.

title.children: More than 200mm rain to hit sodden north Queensland over coming days

image.altText: Members of Women Against Cane Toads gather aorund a toad being held by its leg

props.synopsis: The ladies of Women Against Cane Toads take matters into their own hands, going toad hunting to try and reduce the number of pests wreaking havoc on their community.

title.children: Grassroots groups tackling Australia's most harmful predators

image.altText: Adam hunter holds his finger up to celebrate during an AFL game for the West Coast Eagles.

props.synopsis: Former West Coast Eagles player Adam Hunter is found dead in his hometown of Bunbury aged 43, the third death to rock the AFL community this week.

title.children: Another death shocks AFL as premiership Eagle Adam Hunter dies aged 43

image.altText: Luis Rubiales wearing a black blazer and white shirt with no tie raising his right hand in a wave

props.synopsis: The Spanish men's football coach Luis de la Fuente told Madrid's high court that he did not discuss the controversial kiss with national federation officials after it happened.

title.children: Spain football coach tells Rubiales trial he didn't discuss Hermoso kiss

image.altText: Female hand picking up a bottle of white wine from a supermarket shelf.

props.synopsis: Public health experts are concerned the alcohol industry may have deliberately delayed the inclusion of pregnancy warnings across products after research found one in three alcoholic beverages didn't have warning labels around the time labelling was made mandatory.

title.children: Alcohol industry accused of delaying mandatory pregnancy warnings on labels

image.altText: A man wearing fatigued and a helmet with "TV" on his backpack walks towards a military helicopter

props.synopsis: ABC's Matthew Doran follows the Royal Jordanian Air Force on one of its mercy missions into Gaza.

title.children: ABC becomes first Australian crew into Gaza as part of Jordanian aid mission

image.altText: Vladimir Putin holding a microphone

props.synopsis: Russia was banned from the Eurovision Song Contest following the country's invasion of Ukraine.

title.children: Putin revives Soviet-era rival to Eurovision after Russia banned from contest

image.altText: Two men wearing white collared shirts sit at a wooden table in a wooden paneled room.

props.synopsis: Richard Balanson says when one suffers a disease "you begin to accumulate friends" who have their own story with the same illness. Now, Richard, along with friend Michael Katz, are financing a new fight to defeat Parkinson's Disease.

title.children: Friends unite to fight Parkinson's Disease with free research resource

image.altText: Hundreds of people gathered on a beach.

props.synopsis: Charlize Zmuda was swimming at Woorim Beach when she was fatally injured on Monday.

title.children: More than a thousand gather at vigil for 17yo killed in shark attack

image.altText: A man and woman stand arm in arm smiling at each other.

props.synopsis: Experts are calling on the government to implement strategies that will better predict future Ozempic shortages.

title.children: Australians with diabetes feeling the squeeze from Ozempic shortage

image.altText: A harvester in a field.

props.synopsis: There are fears US tariffs could lead to increased competition in key markets for Australian commodities and dampen demand in our biggest markets.

title.children: What would an era of protectionism mean for Australia?

image.altText: Police officers gathering at a crime scene at dusk.

props.synopsis: NSW Police say the one-year-old girl was found unresponsive in a vehicle on Marana Road at Earlwood on Tuesday afternoon.

title.children: Child found dead in car outside childcare centre in Sydney's south-west

image.altText: A woman's hands holding a green leaf out from a bush.

props.synopsis: From tea to cosmetics, lemon myrtle is becoming an increasingly popular ingredient. But growing the trees to meet demand is easier said than done.

title.children: Lemon myrtle demand is growing but propagating trees is difficult

image.altText: Journalist Antoinette Lattouf, centre, arrives at the Federal Court of Australia with two male lawyers either side of her

props.synopsis: Freelance journalist Antoinette Lattouf recalled being given a suggestion to "keep a low profile" on social media but said she was not directed to avoid posting on social media altogether.

title.children: Antoinette Lattouf tells court she wasn't directed to avoid social media
